repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Congo - Emergency Recovery and
            Community Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Recovery and
            Community Support Project for Republic of Congo were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a
            project implemented in a weak institutional environment
            needs a powerful champion in the administrative and
            political apparatus if far reaching reforms addressing
            multi-sectoral needs have to be implemented. There was a
            window of opportunity at the end of the conflicts for
            launching some critical reforms, and the project
            successfully laid the groundwork for a number of
            improvements to the institutional environment. However, the
            Project Coordination and Implementation Unit (PCIU) did not
            have the means to facilitate the dialogue and complete the
            reform process. An inter-ministerial committee regrouping
            all the involved ministries, and presided by e.g. the Prime
            Minister, could have advanced adoption of the reforms and
            their implementation. The delays in implementing
            decentralization reforms also show that reforms should be
            implemented incrementally and in well defined phases. The
            post-conflict environment can be used to create conditions
            for inclusiveness and build a solid base for private sector
            participation in the reconstruction efforts and for
            launching reforms. Gradual mainstreaming of project
            activities into initially weak sector ministries is
            necessary to assure sustainability.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Congo - Emergency Recovery and
            Community Support Project : environmental and social impact study

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social impact
            study for the Emergency Recovery and Community Support
            Project for the Republic of Congo identifies negative
            environmental impacts and proposes measures to mitigate them
            For the project components of local investment priorities,
            rural road construction, water supply and sanitation, and
            support to community organizations (nongovernmental
            organizations), micro-projects may cover these activities:
            constructing schools, markets, and social centers; extending
            electrification networks; rehabilitating pathways leading to
            agricultural markets, tourist centers, providing water
            supply infrastructure, building embankments, providing fish
            to develop aquaculture, and harnessing solar energy, among
            them. Negative impacts that may result include
            deforestation, soil erosion, destruction of animal habitats,
            sedimentation, runoff, water body pollution from chemicals
            and fertilizer overuse, disruption of water flow; air
            pollution from dust and gas emissions, pollution from
            worksite waste, noise, traffic congestion, accident risks
            among workers and traffic accidents involving residents and
            animals crossing the site, farmland degradation,
            encroachment, poaching, increase in prostitution and moral
            depravity, transmission of infectious diseases-particularly
            HIV/AIDS, child labor, unauthorized exploitation of forest
            resources and poaching in protected areas, water-borne
            diseases, social conflicts, resource overexploitation,
            disturbance of cultural heritage sites, risk of substitution
            of local species by exotic species, and the use of
            pesticides leading to water table pollution, animal
            contamination, food contamination, and packaging
            mismanagement, among other impacts.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Congo - Emergency Recovery and
            Community Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Recovery
            and Community Support Project for the Republic of Congo is
            to assist the recovery of communities living in smaller
            municipalities and rural areas (i.e. all areas outside the
            two main cities of  Brazzaville and Pointe Noire). The
            program comprises four components: (i) Financing of priority
            local investments; (ii) Support to community organizations
            (iii) Capacity enhancement for central and local
            governments; and (iv) Balance of payments support. The
            Project is  expected to assist Congo's stabilization
            and recovery process by: (i) contributing to improving
            living conditions in areas which to date have received
            limited external support and where poverty is  acute; (ii)
            helping strengthen civil society in rural areas and small
            towns; (iii) facilitating the decentralization process and
            the effective provision of basic social services outside
            Brazzaville and Pointe Noire; and (iv) helping maintain the
            pace of economic reforms. The main risks are the possibility
            of renewed violence in some areas, difficulties on the path
            to reform, and a compromised administrative capacity for implementation.
